repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
I'm well aware that this isn't the right way to do it.

This feels like it should be done in a transform somewhere but it isn't obvious which one is right. I'm just putting doing this to test the idea.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7757,6 +7773,10 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
             self.else_clause.analyse_declarations(env)
 
     def analyse_expressions(self, env):
+        dummy = object()
+        in_try_block = getattr(env, "in_try_block", dummy)
+        env.in_try_block = True

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
       in_try_block  int  track if we're in a try...except or try...finally block
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -110,6 +110,7 @@ class ControlFlow(object):
        entries     set    tracked entries
        loops       list   stack for loop descriptors
        exceptions  list   stack for exception descriptors
+       in_try_block  int  track if we're in a try...except or try...finally blcok

comment_data.body:
This may seem excessive, but I don't see a reason to apply arbitrary limits.
```suggestion
     cdef public Py_ssize_t in_try_block
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,6 +58,8 @@ cdef class ControlFlow:
 
      cdef public dict assmts
 
+     cdef public int in_try_block

comment_data.body:
Let's not call this `body`. It confused me since I was excepting a function body, until I realised it was only a function call, and then it started changing meaning along the way.

Also, there is no reason why all of this has to go into a single C code line, right? Chaining an `if` in C with unrelated code seems very brittle. Just generate the code sequentially, as usual, and all problems should go away.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2332,8 +2335,17 @@ def put_pymethoddef_wrapper(self, entry):
             if method_noargs in method_flags:
                 # Special NOARGS methods really take no arguments besides 'self', but PyCFunction expects one.
                 func_cname = Naming.method_wrapper_prefix + func_cname
-                self.putln("static PyObject *%s(PyObject *self, CYTHON_UNUSED PyObject *arg) {return %s(self);}" % (
-                    func_cname, entry.func_cname))
+                body = "%s(self)" % entry.func_cname

comment_data.body:
This is making the non-local assumption that `put_add_traceback()` issues a single command. If that ever stops being true, this code may lead to subtle bugs. Curly braces are cheap in C, let's just use them.

Also, we may be able to use `__Pyx_PyErr_Occurred()` here, which avoids a lookup of the thread state (if it has been looked up before, so not sure if this always applies).

An alternative might be a C flag variable that remembers when no exception was set.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2184,6 +2184,8 @@ def assure_gil(code_path, code=code):
                 # code.put_trace_exception()
 
                 assure_gil('error')
+                if code.funcstate.error_without_exception:
+                    code.put("if (PyErr_Occurred()) ")
                 code.put_add_traceback(self.entry.qualified_name)

comment_data.body: Is this `isinstance()` check needed? What else should there be when the parent is a C class scope?

comment_data.body:
I considered C flag variables and decided it was a little more complicated, although probably more efficient. There's a third option that might work though:

currently the code generated is:
```
error_label:
Py_XDECREF(cleanup_code)
__Pyx_Add_Traceback(....)
```

If we could reorder it to:

```
error_label:
__Pyx_AddTraceback(...)
stop_iteration_label:
__Pyx_XDECREF(variable_cleanup)
```

then that'd be very simple. I wasn't sure if there was a good reason to add the traceback after the cleanup though.

                 # code.put_trace_exception()
 
                 assure_gil('error')
+                if code.funcstate.error_without_exception:
+                    code.put("if (PyErr_Occurred()) ")
                 code.put_add_traceback(self.entry.qualified_name)

comment_data.body:
I couldn't immediately see how to use `__Pyx_PyErr_Occurred` (I think I need to generate a threadstate temp?) so I've left this suggestion for the moment.

But added the curly braces

@@ -2184,6 +2184,8 @@ def assure_gil(code_path, code=code):
                 # code.put_trace_exception()

+                if code.funcstate.error_without_exception:

comment_data.body:
I've switched to using a C flag variable now.

On a quick microbenchmark (essentially a simplified version of `list(reimplementation_of_range(10))` I can't see any difference between a flag variable and `PyErr_Occurred()`. Both of those give a 30% speed up vs the current Cython master and a 90% speedup vs plain Python.

Therefore the change is worthwhile I think, but it isn't worth worrying about exactly how we detect the lack of error.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2184,6 +2184,8 @@ def assure_gil(code_path, code=code):
                 # code.put_trace_exception()
 
                 assure_gil('error')
+                if code.funcstate.error_without_exception:
+                    code.put("if (PyErr_Occurred()) ")
                 code.put_add_traceback(self.entry.qualified_name)

Apply suggestions from code review
